data.title: University of Michigan William L. Clements Library
data.text:
The Bing Crosby collection includes 21 letters and documents from Crosby's professional and personal life, three photographs or photograph reproductions, and one autograph musical quotation. Most letters and documents are in regards to Crosby's film projects during the 1940s and 1950s. Multiple documents pertain to the film White Christmas, including a letter confirming the early script approval by the Paramount Picture Company, and a planning document for the presentation of names in the credits.

See the box and folder listing below for details about each item in the collection.

Bing Crosby, was born in 1903 as Harry Lillis Crosby, in Tacoma, Washington. Crosby became a popular singer, actor and songwriter, and was considered one of the most well-known celebrities of the 20th century. Among his most notable film credits are Holiday Inn (1942), Going My Way (1944), and White Christmas (1954). He was a successful businessman and active sportsman. Crosby died from a heart attack on a golf course near Madrid, Spain in 1977.

The Bing Crosby Collection was compiled by manuscripts collector Dr. D. N. Diedrich (1935-2018) and is part of the Clements Library's Duane Norman Diedrich Collection.
